title: 113_hr2474
content: The Act titled "Community Lending and Small Business Jobs Act of 2013" and the Small Business Leg-Up Act of 2013 aim to support small businesses through lending and growth opportunities in underserved populations. The Congress acknowledges the historical lack of affordable credit for families and small businesses in under-served areas. The financial crisis of 2008 worsened access to capital for entrepreneurs, hindering job creation and economic growth. Small business investments not only create jobs but also boost the local tax base, funding essential community services. The Community Development Financial Institutions Fund is crucial for targeted investments in underserved families, improving economic outcomes nationwide. Providing the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund with a capital infusion will efficiently leverage Federal investment for small business lending in America. Transfer of unobligated funds from Small Business Lending Fund to CDFI Fund upon expiration of investment authority. Proceeds from purchases to be transferred to CDFI Fund. Small Business Capital Investment Program. SEC. 104. SMALL BUSINESS CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM to increase credit availability for small businesses. The Small Business Capital Investment Program aims to increase credit availability for small businesses by making capital investments in eligible community development financial institutions. The program is structured similarly to the Small Business Lending Fund Program authorized under the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010. The Small Business Capital Investment Program deposits payments and proceeds into the Fund for eligible community development financial institutions to apply for capital investments not exceeding 10 percent of total assets. The authority to make investments continues as long as funds are available. The Small Business Leg-Up Act of 2013 authorizes $4,000,000 for the Program, with interest payments covering administrative costs. The Administrator can issue regulations for implementation, and eligible community development financial institutions can apply for capital investments not exceeding 10 percent of total assets. The definition of a 'development financial institution' is a community development financial institution with assets of $10,000,000,000 or less. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the table of contents for the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. Title II of the Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2013 introduces a Small Business Capital Investment Program to increase credit availability for small businesses. This title may be cited as the "Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2013". Additionally, it includes a Microenterprise Technical Assistance and Capacity Building Program. Title II of the Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2013 introduces amendments to the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. These changes expand definitions related to entrepreneurs operating in investment areas and modify the permitted uses of assistance under the Act. The amendments to the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 include provisions for advertising training and technical assistance, increasing targeted assistance to 60 percent, and considering economic impacts when reducing matching requirements. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will submit a report with recommendations for improving the microenterprise technical assistance grant program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a Microenterprise Coordinator must be established within one year. The Small Business Administration will establish the position of Microenterprise Coordinator within one year of the Act's enactment. The Coordinator's duties include maximizing the contributions of microenterprises to the economy, coordinating federal assistance programs, and ensuring underserved entrepreneurs are included in these programs. The Small Business Administration will establish a Microenterprise Coordinator position to oversee federal programs supporting microenterprises. The Coordinator will compile and publish an annual list of these programs and promote public-private partnerships for entrepreneurship. Microenterprise is defined as per the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. The Small Business Administration will establish an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship to support young entrepreneurs. The Small Business Administration will establish an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship with a Director appointed to oversee programs promoting youth entrepreneurship through grants, partnerships, and advertising campaigns. The Small Business Administration's Office of Youth Entrepreneurship will sponsor and support youth entrepreneurship competitions, study and promote Federal activities supporting entrepreneurship education, and establish public and private youth entrepreneurship education opportunities. The Director will also establish grant programs for technical assistance and curriculum development for individuals under 25 years of age. The Director may provide grants to a covered entity for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, including topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. Covered entities must submit an application detailing the curriculum and grant fund usage. The Director provides grants to covered entities for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, focusing on topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. Covered entities must submit an application outlining grant fund usage, goals, and progress measurement. At least 25% of funds are allocated to assist youth in investment areas. The Director provides grants to covered entities for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, focusing on topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. At least 25% of funds are allocated to assist youth in investment areas. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislation on forgiving and deferring student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation. SEC. 204. GAO STUDY AND REPORT. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the economic impact of youth entrepreneurs deferring student loan repayments, increasing participation of individuals under 25 in the microloan program, alternative creditworthiness methods for youth entrepreneurship, and actions Congress can take to promote youth entrepreneurship. A report must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House and Senate Small Business Committees on the study's results conducted under this Act.
